extracted_information: Comprehensive guidelines for cognitive accessibility covering considerations for individuals with cognition and learning disabilities, including strategies for managing working memory, attention span, cognitive load reduction, and specific design patterns.

WCAG_Guidelines_for_Cognitive_Accessibil: Guideline 1.3: Adaptable content - Content should be presentable in different ways without losing information or structure (e.g., responsive layouts, single-column mobile design, narration tool compatibility).
Guideline 2.2: Time - Users must have enough time to read and use content.
Guideline 2.4: Navigable - Provide ways to help users navigate, find content, and determine their location.
Guideline 3.1: Readable - Make text content readable and understandable.
Guideline 3.2: Predictable - Web pages should appear and operate in predictable ways, maintaining consistency.
Guideline 3.3: Input Assistance - Help users avoid and correct mistakes during data entry.

items: Delivering content in more than one way (e.g., text-to-speech, video).
Providing easily-understood content (e.g., plain-language standards).
Focusing attention on important content.
Minimizing distractions (e.g., unnecessary content, advertisements).
Providing consistent web page layout and navigation.
Incorporating familiar elements (e.g., blue unvisited, purple visited underlined links).
Dividing processes into logical, essential steps with progress indicators.
Making website authentication as easy as possible without compromising security.
Making forms easy to complete (e.g., clear error messages, error recovery).
Preserving user data upon re-authentication after an expired session.
Providing warnings about inactivity that could result in data loss, specifying timeout duration.
Ensuring link text clearly conveys meaning, especially for users navigating by link lists.
Providing a quick and easy-to-reference description of the screen's main point using the `<title>` element.
Using clear and descriptive headings and labels so users can easily find information and understand relationships, benefiting those with limited short-term memory.

Allowing users to pause, stop, hide, or control moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information if it starts automatically, lasts more than five seconds, and is presented in parallel with other content, unless essential.
Enabling users to postpone or suppress interruptions (except emergencies).
Allowing users to request content updates rather than auto-updating.
Making nonessential alerts optional.
Minimizing distractions on the page.
Allowing users to turn off or adjust time limits (e.g., to at least 10 times the original limit) or eliminating time constraints altogether.
Providing a buffer of at least 20 seconds to extend timeout duration by a factor of 10 with an action (e.g., hitting space bar).
Providing a toggle for longer or no session time limits for timed content (forms, reading exercises, training materials).
Declaring the language of the page and any content not in that main language using the `lang` attribute.
Defining unusual words and word usage (idioms, colloquialisms, jargon) inline, linked, within a glossary, or to an online dictionary.
Providing expanded forms of abbreviations the first time they are used, potentially with the `<abbr>` element.
Writing content clearly: short, simple words; short sentences; active voice in present tense; correct grammar and spelling.
Providing text summaries (TL;DR) at a low reading level.
Using accompanying visuals to explain ideas, events, and processes.
Ensuring context changes only occur through intentional user activation, not just focus.
Requiring explicit user action (e.g., a submit button) for changes in state, and describing what will happen beforehand.

Conveying automated error detection clearly: described in text, specific, identify incomplete/invalid fields, focus on error, summary for multiple errors, text with icons/images/color, feedback on successful submission.
Providing instructions for user input at the start of forms, using labels (`<label>`, `<fieldset>`, `<legend>`), descriptive labels close to input, and example formats for specific input.
Providing error suggestions when automatically detected.
Implementing mechanisms (review, confirmation, reversibility) for submissions with legal, financial, or significant consequences.
Providing context-sensitive help, form instructions, spell checking, suggestions, and links to support material.

features.category: Design Patterns for Users with Cognitive Disabilities
items: Consistent web page layout and navigation.
Consistent navigation order between pages (same links, same location, uniform navigation bar).
Consistent labeling for identical functions (button labels, alt text for icons, iconography).
Using norms and not changing browser defaults (e.g., back button), and warning users about redirects.
Maintaining focus order (DOM order matching visual and tabbing order).
Ensuring focused elements are visibly focused (don't alter or remove browser's default `:focus` styling unless making it more obvious).
Using `<title>` element for document titles.
Employing clear and descriptive headings and labels for content sections.
Providing multiple ways to find content (e.g., table of contents, site map, search functionality, sequential exploration).
Offering mechanisms like skip links to bypass blocks of content repeated on multiple pages.
Indicating current location within a site or application using breadcrumbs, site maps, or 'current' page indicators in navigation.
Providing pronunciation guidance for words (immediately following, linked lists, glossary, `<ruby>` element, glyphs/diacritical marks with turn-off mechanism and guide).

statistics.US_Disability_Statistics_2018: 1 in 4 U.S. citizens have a disability; cognitive impairment is the most common for young people.

terminology_differences.United_Kingdom: 'Intellectual disabilities' commonly called 'learning disabilities' or 'learning difficulties'.
